title: German submarine U-183
text:
German submarine "U-183" was a <a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine%23Type%20IXC/40">Type IXC/40</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of the German Navy ("<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>") during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. She was <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 1 April 1942, one of the first IXC/40 boats, somewhat larger and faster than the <a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine">IXC</a> type. She began her service life in the <a href="4th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">4th U-boat Flotilla</a>, a training organization, moving on to the <a href="2nd%20U-boat%20Flotilla">2nd</a>, then the <a href="33rd%20U-boat%20Flotilla">33rd Flotilla</a>, both operational or "front" outfits.
"U-183" was in the first wave of "Monsun boats" or <a href="Monsun%20Gruppe">Monsun "Gruppe"</a>, which operated in the <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> from Japanese bases in the occupied <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies">Dutch East Indies</a> and <a href="British%20Malaya">British Malaya</a>, mostly <a href="Penang">Penang</a>.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine%23Type%20IXC/40">German Type IXC/40 submarines</a> were slightly larger than the original <a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine%23Type%20IXC">Type IXC</a>s. "U-183" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. The U-boat had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="MAN%20SE">MAN</a> M 9 V 40/46 <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> four-stroke, nine-cylinder <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Siemens-Schuckert">Siemens-Schuckert</a> 2 GU 345/34 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-183" was fitted with six <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and two at the stern), 22 <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="10.5%20cm%20SK%20C/32%20naval%20gun">SK C/32 naval gun</a>, 180 rounds, and a <a href="3.7%20cm%20SK%20C/30">SK C/30</a> as well as a <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft gun. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of forty-eight.
Service history.
After serving in the Atlantic, "U-183" sailed from France in July 1943, arriving at Penang on 27 October, and operated in the zone for almost two years. She carried out six war patrols, and was sunk on 23 April 1945, 15 days before <a href="German%20Instrument%20of%20Surrender">Germany's surrender</a>, by the American submarine in the <a href="Java%20Sea">Java Sea</a>. Only one crew member survived.
In November 2013 the wreck of either this submarine or has been located.
Wolfpacks.
"U-183" took part in three <a href="Wolfpack%20%28naval%20tactic%29">wolfpack</a>s, namely:
